TEI:
Kalittokai 70.
itu parattaiyiṟ pirintuvanta talaivaṉ tōḻiyai vāyilvēṇṭa avaḷ vāyiṉērvāḷ neruṅkik kūṟiyatu.
maṇiniṟa malarppoykai makiḻntāṭu maṉṉantaṉ
ṉaṇimiku cēvalai yakalaṭai maṟaitteṉak
katumeṉak kāṇātu kalaṅkiyam maṭappeṭai
matiniḻa ṉīruṭkaṇ ṭatuveṉa vuvantōṭit
tuṉṉattaṉ ṉetirvarūun tuṇaikaṇṭu mikanāṇip
paṉmala riṭaippukūum paḻaṉañcē rūrakēḷ;
nalanīppat tuṟantemmai nalkāynī viṭutaliṟ
palanāḷum paṭātakaṇ pāyalkoṇ ṭiyaipavāṟ
ṟuṇaimalark kōtaiyār vaikalum pārāṭṭa
maṇamaṉait tatumpuniṉ maṇamuḻavan teṭuppumē;
akalanī tuṟattali ṉaḻutōvā vuṇkaṇem
putalvaṉai meytīṇṭap poruntuta liyaipavā
ṉiṉakkotta nallārai neṭunakart tantuniṉ
ṟamarpāṭun tuṇaṅkaiyu ḷaravamvan teṭuppumē;
vārāynī tuṟattaliṉ varuntiya vemakkāṅkē
nīritaḻ pularākkaṇ ṇimaikūmpa viyaipavā
ṉēriḻai nallārai neṭunakart tantuniṉ
ṟērpūṇṭa neṭunaṉmāṉ ṟeṇmaṇivan teṭuppumē;
eṉavāṅku,
melliyāṉ cevimutaṉ mēlvantāṉ kālaipō
lellān tuyilō veṭuppuka niṉpeṇṭi
rilli ṉeḻīiya yāḻtaḻīik kallāvāyp
pāṇaṉ pukutarāk kāl.
Listen, oh man from a village near the paddy fields, where,
of the geese that joyfully bathe in the pond with blossoms of sapphire colour,
the pretty youthful she-bird, having been upset at not immediately seeing,
because the wide leaves hid [it], her very ornate gander,
saw the moon’s shadow in the water [and], thinking [it was] that, ran [there] in joy,
[and] when approaching, it saw [its] mate coming towards it [and] was very embarrassed:
Because you, ungranting, abandoned [us and] let go of us so that [our] beauty leaves,
[our] eyes that did not close for many a day indeed agree in taking to the bed;
while those with garlands of matching blossoms daily praise,
your marriage drum that sounds in the marriage house comes [and] wakes [us] up.
Because you have abandoned [us] in order to depart [our] kajal eyes that do not stop crying
indeed agree to close when we touch the body of our son;
the sounds in the Tuṇaṅkai that their people sing, having brought to the high mansion
good women who are equal to you, come [and] wake [us] up.
Because you who do not come have abandoned [us], for us thus
the eyes on whose lids the water does not dry indeed agree to close for a moment;
the clear bells of the tall good horses yoked to your chariot after bringing
good women with fine jewels to the high mansion comes [and] wake [us] up.
That is to say,
like on who comes in the morning right into the ear one who is of soft nature,
all [attempts at] sleep, ah, let them be interrupted –
before the bard with the untaught voice enters,
holding [his] lute that is raised in the house of your women.
